# Lists

Lists are a common way to organize and present data on webpages. You can easily create elegant unordered lists with ul, ordered lists with ol, and description lists with dl. ul will show bullets, ol will show numbers for ordering, and dl will indent itself if the list item is a sub item. In addition to basic lists, you can create navigation menus and custom drop down menus.

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  1. Item 1
  2. Item 2
Main description
Sub item description
    <div class="row">
<div class="col-4">
    <ul>
        <li>Item 1</li>
        <li>Item 2</li>
    </ul>
</div>
<div class="col-4">
    <ol>
        <li>Item 1</li>
        <li>Item 2</li>
    </ol>
</div>
<div class="col-4">
    <dl>
        <dt>Main description</dt>
        <dd>Sub item description</dd>
    </dl>
</div>
</div>
Types

Bulleted (Default)

A standard list with bullets preceding the list item.

  • Apple
  • Google
  • Facebook
  • Microsoft
<ul>
    <li>Apple</li>
    <li>Google</li>
    <li>Facebook</li>
    <li>Microsoft</li>
</ul>

Numbered

An ordered list with numbers for each item.

  1. Apple
  2. Google
  3. Facebook
  4. Microsoft
<ol>
    <li>Apple</li>
    <li>Google</li>
    <li>Facebook</li>
    <li>Microsoft</li>
</ol>

Plain

An list with no item decorations.

  • Apple
  • Google
  • Facebook
  • Microsoft
<ul class="no-bullets">
    <li>Apple</li>
    <li>Google</li>
    <li>Facebook</li>
    <li>Microsoft</li>
</ul>

Details

A list designed for detailed descriptions.

Apple
Apple Inc. is an American multinational technology company headquartered in Cupertino, California that designs, develops, and sells consumer electronics, ...
<dl>
    <dt>Apple</dt>
    <dd>Apple Inc. is an American multinational technology company headquartered in Cupertino, California that designs, develops, and sells consumer electronics, ...</dd>
</dl>
Nested Lists

Cirrus will automatically style and pad nested lists so you don't have to. Just add the nested-list class to the div containing the list.

  • List Item 1
  • List Item 2
  • List Item 3
    • List Item 3.a
    • List Item 3.b
    • List Item 3.c
      • List Item 3.c.i
      • List Item 3.c.ii
      • List Item 3.c.iii
  1. List Item 1
  2. List Item 2
  3. List Item 3
    1. List Item 3.a
    2. List Item 3.b
    3. List Item 3.c
      1. List Item 3.c.i
      2. List Item 3.c.ii
      3. List Item 3.c.iii
  • List Item 1
  • List Item 2
  • List Item 3
    1. List Item 3.a
    2. List Item 3.b
    3. List Item 3.c
      • List Item 3.c.i
      • List Item 3.c.ii
      • List Item 3.c.iii
<!-- Unordered List -->
<ul>
    <li>List Item 1</li>
    <li>List Item 2</li>
    <li>List Item 3
        <ul>
            <li>List Item 3.a</li>
            <li>List Item 3.b</li>
            <li>List Item 3.c
                <ul>
                    <li>List Item 3.c.i</li>
                    <li>List Item 3.c.ii</li>
                    <li>List Item 3.c.iii</li>
                </ul>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </li>
</ul>

# Menu Lists

The list styles in Cirrus can easily be extended to handle more complex menu structures for websites and web apps.

Standard Menus

Below are some examples of how menu lists can be used in websites as a list of links. In these examples, almost all of the functionality of lists in Cirrus is demonstrated.

Richard Hendricks.

Founder and CEO of Pied Piper.

  • News Feed
  • Messenger

    • Shortcuts

  • Some App 
<div class="col-4">
<div class="frame">
    <div class="frame-header">
        <div class="tile level">
            <div class="tile-icon">
                <figure class="avatar">
                    <img src="https://media.licdn.com/mpr/mpr/shrinknp_200_200/p/6/005/069/06b/2a8cd67.jpg"/>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="tile-container">
                <p class="tile-title no-margin">Richard Hendricks</b>.</p>
                <p class="tile-subtitle no-margin">Founder and CEO of Pied Piper.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>

    <div class="frame-body">
        <ul class="menu">
            <li class="divider"></li>
            <li class="menu-item selected">
                <div class="menu-addon right">
                    <span class="icon">
                        <i class="fa fa-ellipsis-h small" aria-hidden="true"></i>
                    </span>
                </div>
                <a href="#">News Feed</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Messenger</a>
            </li>
            <p class="menu-title uppercase">Shortcuts</p>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Some App</a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </div>
</div>

In the list above, a frame was used as the container along with a menu divider, list items with the menu-item class with a menu-addon, and the menu-title.

Unsplash Viewer

Rate this photo.

Did you like the photo?

  • Yes
  • No 
<div class="card">
    <div class="card-container">
        <div class="card-image" style="background-image: url(https://source.unsplash.com/random/640x480)">
        </div>

        <div class="title-container">
            <p class="title">Unsplash Viewer</p><span class="subtitle">Rate this photo.</span>
        </div>
    </div>
    <div class="content">
        <p>Did you like the photo?</p>
        <ul class="menu">
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#"><span class="icon"><i class="fa fa-check small"></i></span>
                Yes</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#"><span class="icon"><i class="fa fa-times small"></i></span>
                No</a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </div>
</div>

The example above uses a card with menu-item list items as the choices.

Bookmarks

  • Github
  • Tech News
    • Hacker News
    • Lobste.rs
  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Instagram 
<div class="frame">
    <div class="frame-header">
        <p class="title no-margin">Bookmarks</p>
    </div>
    <div class="frame-body">
        <ul class="menu">
            <li class="divider" data-label="TECH"></li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Github</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item selected">
                <div class="menu-addon">
                    <span class="icon">
                        <i class="fa fa-folder small"></i>
                    </span>
                </div>
                <a href="#">Tech News</a>
                <ul class="menu">
                    <li class="menu-item">
                        <a href="#">Hacker News</a>
                    </li>
                    <li class="menu-item">
                        <a href="#">Lobste.rs</a>
                    </li>
                </ul>
            </li>
        </ul>
        <ul class="menu">
            <li class="divider" data-label="PROCRASTINATION"></li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Facebook</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Twitter</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Instagram</a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </div>
    <div class="frame-footer">
        <!-- Insert some controls here -->
    </div>
</div>

The list above uses dividers with a label and nested lists. The menu items with the accent color have the selected class attached to the list item.

Navigation Menus

Creating navigation menus using lists is also a piece of cake with support for list nesting in a clean design.

  • Real-Time
  • Audience
    • Overview
    • Active Users
    • Lifetime Value BETA
    • Cohort Analytics BETA
  • Acquisition 
<ul class="menu">
    <li class="menu-item">
        <div class="menu-addon">
            <span class="icon"><i class="fa fa-clock-o"></i></span>
        </div>
        <a href="#">Real-Time</a>
    </li>
    <li class="menu-item selected">
        <div class="menu-addon">
            <span class="icon"><i class="fa fa-user"></i></span>
        </div>
        <a href="#">Audience</a>
        <ul class="menu">
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Overview</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Active Users</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Lifetime Value <sup>BETA</sup></a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Cohort Analytics <sup>BETA</sup></a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </li>
    <li class="menu-item">
        <div class="menu-addon">
            <span class="icon">
                <i class="fa fa-share-alt"></i>
            </span>
        </div>
        <a href="#">Acquisition</a>
    </li>
</ul>
Dropdown Menus

Drop down menus are easy to configure in Cirrus using lists. Simply wrap the button and the menu in a menu-dropdown container and Cirrus will automatically style all the components for the dropdown menu. To display the menu on the right side, just add the menu-right class to the menu-dropdown container. These dropdown menus can work straight out of the box and also support JavaScript events when needed.

  • Google Chrome
  • Firefox
  • Polarity
  • Google Chrome
  • Firefox
  • Polarity
  • Google Chrome
  • Firefox
  • Polarity 
<div class="menu-dropdown">
    <div class="btn-group">
        <button class="btn-accent">Dropdown</button><button class="btn-accent btn-small btn-dropdown"><span class="icon"><i class="fa fa-caret-down small"></i></span></button>
        <ul class="menu">
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Google Chrome</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Firefox</a>
            </li>
            <li class="menu-item">
                <a href="#">Polarity</a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </div>
</div>
<div class="menu-dropdown dropdown-right">
    <button class="btn-accent btn-dropdown">
        Dropdown </span class="icon"><i class="fa fa-caret-down"></i><span>
    </button>
    <ul class="menu">
        <li class="menu-item">
            <a href="#">Google Chrome</a>
        </li>
        <li class="menu-item">
            <a href="#">Firefox</a>
        </li>
        <li class="menu-item">
            <a href="#">Polarity</a>
        </li>
    </ul>
</div>
<div class="menu-dropdown">
    <button class="btn-transparent btn-dropdown">
        Dropdown </span class="icon"><i class="fa fa-caret-down"></i><span>
    </button>
    <ul class="menu">
        <li class="menu-item">
            <a href="#">Google Chrome</a>
        </li>
        <li class="menu-item">
            <a href="#">Firefox</a>
        </li>
        <li class="menu-item">
            <a href="#">Polarity</a>
        </li>
    </ul>
</div>

# Trees

A tree is a CSS only list that lays out menu-items in a vertical menu with a toggle. A tree has children that are denoted with the tree-item class. The tree-item can then have menu list of menu-items in the tree-item-body with the title above it being a tree-item-header. The toggle is created by a simple input (checkbox or radiobutton depending on the behavior you want) with a check property.

Regular Tree (Checkboxes)

  • Oak
  • Birch
    • Cedar
    • Loblolly Pine
    • Pitch Pine
  • Mangosteen
  • Durian
  • Jabuticaba
  • Jade Vine
  • Ghost Orchid
  • Corpse Flower

Exclusive Tree (Radio)

  • Oak
  • Birch
  • Mangosteen
  • Durian
  • Jabuticaba
  • Jade Vine
  • Ghost Orchid
  • Corpse Flower

Mixed Tree

  • Menu Item 1
    • Menu Item 1.1
    • Menu Item 1.2
    • Menu Item 1.3
  • Menu Item 3
<!-- Normal Tree Behavior -->
<div class="tree">
    <div class="tree-item">
        <input type="checkbox" id="tree1" class="hide" /> <!-- Allows for multiple trees to be opened or closed -->
        <label class="tree-item-header" for="tree1"> <!-- Title for tree branch, make sure label 'for' matches with input id -->
            <span class="icon">
                <i class="fa fa-chevron-right small"></i> <!-- Dropdown Icon -->
            </span>
            Trees
        </label>
        <div class="tree-item-body"> <!-- Contains the dropdown items -->
            <ul class="menu">
                <!-- Add menu-items... -->

                <li class="menu-item"> <!-- Nested Tree -->
                    <div class="tree">
                        <input type="checkbox" id="tree2" class="hide" />
                        <label class="tree-item-header" for="tree2">
                            <span class="icon">
                                <i class="fa fa-chevron-right small"></i>
                            </span>
                            Evergreens
                        </label>
                        <div class="tree-item-body">
                            <ul class="menu">
                                <!-- Menu items... -->
                            </ul>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                </li>
            </ul>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>
<!-- Add another tree -->

<!-- Mutually exclusive trees use radio buttons as the method of input -->
<div class="tree">
    <div class="tree-item">
        <input type="radio" id="tree3" class="hide" /> <!-- Note the radio button -->
        <label class="tree-item-header" for="tree3">
            <span class="icon">
                <i class="fa fa-chevron-right small"></i>
            </span>
            Fruits
        </label>
        <div class="tree-item-body">
            <ul class="menu">
                <!-- Menu items... -->
            </ul>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>
<!-- Add other trees with radio inputs -->

Keep in mind that the icon is still optional, so creating a list without the dropdown indicator is as simple as excluding the icon from the header.

  • #364b60
  • #169f83
  • #2dcc71
  • #e57d1f
  • #eec10e 
<div class="tree">
    <div class="tree-item">
        <input type="checkbox" id="color1" class="hide" />
        <label class="tree-item-header" for="color1">
            <p class="title no-margin">Color Palette 1</p>
        </label>
        <div class="tree-item-body">
            <ul class="menu">
                <li class="menu-item">
                    <a>#364b60</a>
                </li>
                <li class="menu-item">
                    <a>#169f83</a>
                </li>
                <li class="menu-item">
                    <a>#2dcc71</a>
                </li>
                <li class="menu-item">
                    <a>#e57d1f</a>
                </li>
                <li class="menu-item">
                    <a>#eec10e</a>
                </li>
            </ul>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>
Tree Outline
  • tree will serve as the parent container for the tree list.
    • Each child of the tree must be a tree-item element.
      • An input with the hide class must be the first child with an approriate id to be referenced by the tree-item-header label. The input can either by a checkbox or a radio button depending on the selection mode you want.
      • tree-item-header is the title of the list is the label with an optional slot for an icon. The actual title text is generally placed after the icon,
      • tree-item-body is the body of the tree is the div.
        • menu div serves as the body for the menu-items that are shown/hidden when the user clicks the tree-item-header. Other menus can be nested here as well.

# Tree Nav Layout

A great way to use the tree class is by embedding it inside a tree-nav as a fixed menu on the side of the page. The best way to use the tree-nav is to embed it inside the tree-nav-body. That will serve as the container for all the child elements with the tree-nav on the left side and a tree-nav-content that will house the rest of the page contents with a scrollable view.

For mobile devices (<= 768px), the tree-nav-header will be visble to show a toggle switch to show the tree-nav.

Outline
  • tree-nav-body will be the root element in this layout.
    • tree-nav-header is the fixed header bar that will appear in touch devices (<=768px).
      • An a tag with an href with the ID of the tree-nav with an icon of your choice for the toggle.
    • tree-nav is the sidebar of the page. At the moment, it is only supported in showing the menu on the left side properly for touch devices and desktops.
      • tree-nav-container will be the container that will house the tree element. For more info on making a tree, you can refer to it in the docs here.
    • tree-nav-content is the container that would store the other elements of the page such as text, images, etc.
